text: With this, architecture has made a contribution to human

text: painting and sculpture on the same level, and are the so-called
label: Paragraph

text: fine arts of painting and sculpture and the so-called applied arts

text: had been in the Middle Ages, so in the Baroque. But that mutual

text: sympathy, that common understanding had not always been a

text: matter of course. The Town Hall of Amsterdam and the

label: Paragraph

text: do not belong together. Those who praised the one would not
label: Paragraph

text: necessarily praise the other, and if some did they would do it
label: Paragraph

text: for opposite reasons. Holland in the seventeenth century was
label: Paragraph

text: a middle-class republic. It was here that the figure of the mis-
label: Paragraph

text: understood, the neglected, the starving artist first appeared.
label: Paragraph

text: Moreover, Holland was a Protestant country and not in need of
label: Paragraph

text: the visual arts for worship. The second age of the art that
label: Paragraph

text: mattered being unwelcome was the first middle-class age, the
label: Paragraph

text: nineteenth century, or rather the nineteenth and the later
label: Paragraph

text: eighteenth century which belongs to it. Neglect grew into
label: Paragraph

text: active opposition; art on the other hand in Goya, in Blake, in
label: Paragraph

text: Runge went into a secret language. If you want to understand
label: Paragraph

text: the artist, you must entrust yourself to him and work at it; he is
label: Paragraph

text: no longer going to work for you. Patronage in the old sense was
label: Paragraph

text: dead; what patronage there was to be was as individual, as
label: Paragraph

text: exposed as the artist’s gospel itself. Isolation, half imposed and
label: Paragraph

text: half self-imposed, was the fate of the painters of Barbizon, of
label: Paragraph

text: Courbet, of the Impressionists, of the Post-Impressionists. If
label: Paragraph

text: anything, the pitch of hostility rose. The social development of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture was bound to be different. There never can be an
label: Paragraph

text: architect as isolated as a painter. But while this relative security
label: Paragraph

text: was a gratifying fact for the architect, it was not beneficial for
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. It meant quite simply that in the nineteenth century
label: Paragraph

text: the most ruthlessly creative minds did not choose the profession
label: Paragraph

text: ofthearchitect. This explains toa certain extent the phenomenon
label: Paragraph

text: of the collapse of aesthetic values in so much of the century. It
label: Paragraph

text: also explains why it is that the most forward-pointing work so
label: Paragraph

text: often came from outsiders. The reason why it came from
label: Paragraph

text: engineers is that the century was one of materialism and hence
label: Paragraph

text: of science and technology. No century ever before had seen
label: Paragraph

text: comparable progress in these fields. The progress was made at
label: Paragraph

text: the expense of aesthetic sensibility of the subtle kind that would
label: Paragraph

text: have granted acceptance to Impressionism and Post-Impression-
label: Paragraph

text: ism. The Crystal Palace met with success, but so also did the
label: Paragraph

text: horrors of decorative art displayed in it. Architects’ architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and salon or academy art went together, engineers’ and
label: Paragraph

text: explorers’ architecture and explorers’ are did not.
label: Paragraph

text: But this statement is perhaps too abrupt. The roads followed
label: Paragraph

text: by the best painters, the best craftsmen or manufacturers and
label: Paragraph

text: the best architects did occasionally meet. The earliest was the
label: Paragraph

text: most fruitful meeting; it is that between Morris’s preaching
label: Paragraph

text: and the conversion to craft and design of young painters and
label: Title

text: young architects. Otherwise meetings were mostly much less
label: Paragraph

text: significant. One might perhaps just say that the turn to intimacy,
label: Paragraph

text: the turn away from bombast was of a similar nature in the
label: Paragraph

text: English Domestic Revival and in Impressionism in painting of
label: Paragraph

text: the same years. One can perhaps also say that the elegance of
label: Paragraph

text: facade detail which replaced the grossness and bluster of the
label: Paragraph

text: High Victorian architects corresponds to the elegance of
label: Paragraph

text: Impressionist painting as against Courbet’s. But that does not
label: Paragraph

text: take us very far.
label: Paragraph

text: It is different with Art Nouveau. Here indeed certain painters
label: Paragraph

text: were in full accord with the craftsmen-designers. If Art
label: Paragraph

text: Nouveau is characterized by radical innovation, and by the
label: Paragraph

text: incantation of the curve, then Gauguin certainly belongs to it —
label: Paragraph

text: as one of the illustrations to this survey has already demonstrated
label: Paragraph

text: — and so do the northerners Munch and Toorop and Hodler,
label: Paragraph

text: and to a more limited degree Maurice Denis, Vallotton, the
label: Paragraph

text: Seurat of The Circus, the Signac of the Fénéon portrait. But
label: Paragraph

text: after that moment, the short years about 1900, what happened?
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture went the way of Garnier and Perret, of Loos and
label: Paragraph

text: Hoffmann, of Behrens and Berg, and design the way of the
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund, but painting went the way to Fauvism and Cubism,
label: Paragraph

text: to the Briicke and the Blaue Reiter, to Futurism and Kandinsky.
label: Paragraph

text: It is easy to see the similarities of approach and result in
label: Paragraph

text: Bindesbdll’s plates, Gaudi’s pinnacles of the Sagrada Familia
label: Caption

text: and Picasso’s pottery, but the dates will not match. It is also
label: Paragraph

text: easy to see as one, cubist paintings of the geometrical kind and
label: Paragraph

text: cubic architecture of the 1920s — after all Le Corbusier produced
label: Paragraph

text: both — or Léger’s machine men and the machine-worshippers
label: Title

text: among the architects. But these comparisons are superficial.
label: Paragraph

text: They do not concern the essential change, which is that
label: Paragraph

text: architects and designers once more accepted social respon-
label: Paragraph

text: sibilities, that architecture and design consequently became a
label: Paragraph

text: service, and buildings and objects of daily use were designed not
label: Paragraph

text: only to satisfy the aesthetic wishes of their designers but also to
label: Paragraph

text: fulfil their practical purposes fully and enthusiastically. Painters
label: Paragraph

text: and sculptors moved in exactly the opposite direction. They had
label: Paragraph

text: been cut off from their public already in the nineteenth century.
label: Paragraph

text: Now they were cut off beyond redemption. Courbet shocked
label: Paragraph

text: his public because of his message, but that message was perfectly
label: Paragraph

text: plain to everybody. The Impressionists were attacked for their
label: Paragraph

text: paintings not being recognizable. But that proved a matter of
label: Paragraph

text: visual habits. Their aesthetic aims were still those of Titian and
label: Paragraph

text: Velazquez. Only they had no other than aesthetic aims and that
label: Paragraph

text: deprived them of the sympathy which the public could extend
label: Paragraph

text: as long as the spiritual content of a work of art concerned it.
label: Paragraph

text: To recover these lost spiritual contacts was the most important
label: Paragraph

text: effort of Gauguin, van Gogh, the Symbolists, Munch, Hodler —
label: Paragraph

text: all of them. But they failed, and while from van Gogh’s
label: Paragraph

text: longing for his paintings to be accepted by simple people, like
label: Paragraph

text: the broadsheets they read, there might have been a bridge to
label: Paragraph

text: the architects’ and designers’ endeavours towards a style for all,
label: Paragraph

text: there was none from cubism and the dynamic abstract art of
label: Paragraph

text: Kandinsky.
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius hoped there might be, and the Bauhaus made the
label: Paragraph

text: noble effort of inviting Klee and other abstractionists under its
label: Paragraph

text: roof. No successful effort has been made since. To offer an
label: Paragraph

text: abstract artist a wall in a building, or an abstract sculptor a place
label: Paragraph

text: in a courtyard is no substitute. To force the artist into direct
label: Paragraph

text: social service against his better aesthetic conviction, as is the
label: Paragraph

text: principle of Socialist Realism and was that of National-Socialist
label: Paragraph

text: Realism, is even less of a help. In fact there is no help. The gulf
label: Paragraph

text: between Jackson Pollock and Mies van der Rohe or even Nervi
label: Title

text: is beyond bridging. This book is not the place to suggest
label: Paragraph

text: remedies or foretell the future. Here it must be enough to state
label: Paragraph

text: that what is most disastrous in the visual arts of the twentieth
label: Paragraph

text: century and what is most hopeful was fully in existence by the
label: Paragraph

text: time the Age of the World Wars dawned.
